explanation:
Brief justification for each symbol (why it matters to determine dead code):

- BUGCHECK
  - May abort or otherwise change control flow if the Mode validity check fails. If BUGCHECK stops execution, later code is unreachable; if it only logs, code remains live. Needed to decide if the initial validation makes the rest of the function impossible to execute (dead) in some build/configurations.

- OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ, OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE, OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READWRITE
  - Their values/encoding (enum vs bitmask and bit patterns) determine the semantics of the Mode checks (the BUGCHECK membership test and the later bitwise & operations). Knowing whether these constants overlap or are distinct decides whether the Mode-dependent branches (the two stream->stream_state clears) can ever be executed and whether one of them is redundant.

- OS_ERR_INVALID_ARGUMENT
  - The value passed to BUGCHECK on invalid Mode may affect build-time behavior of BUGCHECK macros or error-handling policies; included to understand consequences of the Mode check.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById
  - Its return semantics (when it returns OS_SUCCESS vs error) and side effects (initializing/acquiring token) determine whether the main body executes. If it always fails or has platform-dependent behavior, subsequent code could be dead.

- OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE
  - Arguments to OS_ObjectIdGetById that may affect its behavior/return. Needed if different lock/type parameters change whether the call succeeds, which affects reachability of the rest of the function.

- OS_SUCCESS
  - The success value used to gate the primary body. Needed to interpret OS_ObjectIdGetById results and whether the function proceeds to potentially live code.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET
  - Macro/function that yields the stream pointer from OS_stream_table and token. Its behavior (e.g., whether it can return NULL or a sentinel) affects whether accesses to stream fields are valid and whether code that manipulates stream state is actually reachable/has effect.

- OS_stream_table
  - The object table being indexed; its layout and contents determine if OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET returns a valid record and if accesses/assignments to that record have observable effects (i.e., whether they are dead).

- OS_stream_internal_record_t
  - Structure definition (members socket_domain, socket_type, stream_state) is required to know field types and whether modifications (bit-clears) affect observable state.

- OS_object_token_t
  - Type of token passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById/Release and OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; needed to understand ownership/locking semantics and side effects that could make code (e.g., OS_ObjectIdRelease) significant.

- OS_SocketDomain_INVALID
  - Value used to test stream->socket_domain. If stream->socket_domain is always different (or always equal) by invariant, the branch setting OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE could be dead or redundant.

- OS_SocketType_STREAM
  - Used to test stream->socket_type; its value and invariants on stream records determine whether the subsequent state-check and error path are ever taken.

- OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED
  - Mask/flag used with stream_state to decide correctness for stream sockets. Its encoding and invariants determine whether the connected-test branch can be taken and thus whether that error path is live.

- OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE, OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE
  - Error codes assigned in the type/state-check branches. If these assignments never occur (due to invariants), those branches would be dead; their presence also influences callers' observed behavior.

- OS_SocketShutdown_Impl
  - The implementation called to perform the real shutdown. Its return behavior determines whether the subsequent writes to stream->stream_state (clearing readable/writable flags) execute. If it always fails or is a no-op, the bit-clearing code may be dead.

- OS_ObjectIdRelease
  - Releases the token and may have observable side effects (unlocking, triggering cleanup). If it must be called for correctness, it is live; if it's a no-op in some builds it could be dead. Needed to decide whether its call is essential.

- OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE, OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE
  - Bit masks that are cleared from stream->stream_state when shutdown succeeds. Their encoding and whether these bits are used elsewhere determine whether the clears are meaningful or removable (i.e., dead assignments).

Overall rationale: to decide if any statement in this function is dead (i.e., executed but removable without changing program behavior) one must know: (a) the control-flow effects of BUGCHECK and OS_ObjectIdGetById (do they prevent execution?), (b) the possible values/encodings of Mode constants (are the Mode-dependent clears ever distinct/necessary?), (c) invariants and contents of the stream record/table (could type/state branches ever be taken?), and (d) whether OS_SocketShutdown_Impl and OS_ObjectIdRelease have side effects that make the subsequent writes to stream state or the release call necessary. The symbols above are the minimal set needed to make that determination.
